intro: Draba macouniana, commonly known as Macoun's whitlow grass, is a flowering plant native to the Pacific Northwest of North America. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes mustard and cabbage plants, and is characterized by its small, clustered flowers and basal leaves. The plant typically grows in moist, open habitats such as meadows and stream banks. It produces small, round seed pods that release tiny seeds when mature. Draba macouniana is an important part of the local flora and contributes to the ecological diversity of its habitat.
